title: APRA has 'misread' Hayne on banker pay
text:
"It is actually inconsistent with Hayne, which recommends that boards take greater responsibility and be accountable to investors."

Wesfarmers chairman Mr Chaney agreed that reducing long-term incentives to 50 per cent, rather than say 80 per cent "won’t diminish an executive’s focus on shareholder returns".

"That is, after all, the main purpose of listed companies, and that is why the investment community object to the 50:50 edict; as well as the vagueness and unmeasurability," he said.

Wesfarmers chairman Michael Chaney says good corporate conduct is the basis of long-term investor value. Photo: Bohdan Warchomij

"It should be clear to any competent executive that a company won’t achieve good shareholder returns over the long term unless it is a good corporate citizen."

Investor groups also warned against the proposal – the Australian Shareholders Association said non-financial measures should account for no more than 30 per cent of bonus metrics.

Global proxy firm ISS was vocal in its dislike for the move, saying "APRA requires that conventional financial metrics be replaced with mostly undisclosed non-financial performance metrics of questionable relevance and impact".

The tension continues to play out in the current shareholder meeting season where Carsales on Friday is among companies that ISS and ASA are recommending against, after moving to 40 per cent non-financial targets.

Advertisement

Investors have “no way of ascertaining if the non-financial measures are robust with the current level of disclosure”, the ASA said.

The Australian Institute of Company Directors and others suggested a "conduct" gateway or board discretion to reduce bonuses paid on financial metrics, rather than the one size fits all approach proposed by APRA.

Graham Bradley says APRA has misread or misunderstood the Hayne commission on pay. Peter Rae

"The regulator is pulling boards in one direction but the investor community are rejecting that approach, so it is putting boards in an invidious position," AICD CEO Angus Armour said.

The AICD said the "unworkable tension" was "compounded by the lack of any clear consensus on acceptable non-financial metrics that should be used".

"We are concerned that the more prescriptive elements in the standard may ultimately work against APRA’s objectives," it said.

It also raised concerns about the deferral of variable remuneration for up to seven years and the clawback of bonuses for up to four years, arguing that this was out of line with the EU and UK.

The directors' club is also deeply concerned at the proposal for boards to approve and actively oversee remuneration policies for a wider group of executives, in some cases adding up to 100 more employees.

Advertisement

Angus Armour says APRA's prescriptive approach will not work. Peter Rae

"The more time they ask boards to invest in direct line of sight on pay, the more it takes away from the critical focus on strategy and broader risks," Mr Armour said. "The level of prescription is not going to work."

The big banks and the Australian Banking Association have also lodged submissions but said they would wait for APRA to release their views.

However, bank sources said they had raised similar concerns to those raised by investors and directors.
description: APRA's plan to overhaul bank bonuses is unworkable and likely to backfire, the peak body for company directors warns.
